plugin._field_explanation: Forge camera and manipulator parameters. Most of these only apply to the camera when you are grabbing >= 1 object.

_field_real.name: max object grab range#max possible distance at which monitor can grab an object. Small objects may not be grabbable at this distance. In absolute distance units.
default grab distance mult#when you spawn an object, it'll be spawned defaultGrabDistanceMultiplier x object.boundingRadius out

_field_real_bounds.name: min-max grab distance mult#auto-zoom brings you no closer/farther than multiplier x object.boundingRadius from grabbed object
minimum grab distance threshold#auto-zoom near can never leave these bounds
maximum grab distance threshold#auto-zoom far can never leave these bounds

_field_real.name: lock-on time#it takes this long (seconds) for the camera to focus on grabbed objects when you lock on
grab-cam soft ceiling movement speed#when we're outside level bounds while grabbing item(s)
grab-cam inward spring constant#these control camera springiness for restoring position when we get blocked from our object
grab-cam outward spring constant#these control camera springiness for restoring position when we get blocked from our object
camera-object distance threshold#How far the camera can get from expected distance to object before we force camera position
translating-objects speed multiplier#When you're grabbing and translating objects, monitor speed is x this
translation speed
rotation speed
monitor boost translation speed
monitor boost rotation speed

_field_block_64.name: jumbotron UI element#This is the UI NodeGraphStack that'll be drawn in-game for Jumbotrons

_field_tag_reference_64.name: jumbotron UI element#This is the UI NodeGraphStack that'll be drawn in-game for Jumbotrons

_field_string_id.name: name^#this is the name that'll display for the jumbotron in-menu
name^#this is the name that'll display for the gobo in-menu
name^#this is the name that'll display for the function in-menu
name^#this is the name that'll display for the screen effect in-menu
name^#this is the name that'll display for the bitmap in-menu
name^#this is the name that'll display for the bitmap in-menu
name^#this is the name that'll display for the lens flare in-menu
name^#this is the name that'll display for the light cone in-menu

_field_block_64.name: rotation snap values#These are the rotation snaps the user can set to

_field_real.name: rotation snap amount (degrees)

_field_block_64.name: translation snap values#These are the translation snaps the user can set to

_field_real.name: translation snap amount (world units)

_field_tag_reference_64.name: forge required resources#This is a list of Forge object tags that'll be force-loaded in Forge game types
rotation handle shader#used on programatically-generated rotation handle rings
path preview shader#used on programatically-generated path previews (like for mancannon paths)

_field_block_64.name: global label values#These are the global megalo labels that provide limited scripting functionality to objects

_field_string_id.name: name^#this is the string id of the actual Megalo label
label display name^#this is the string id of the friendlier display name for the label
label display description^#this is the string id of the display description of what this label does

item.Name: Only spawn if game mode requires

_field_block_64.name: outline shaders#Shaders for different Forge outline types ("grabbed + deleting", "highlighted by networked player", etc.)
Forge Intro Compositions#Since we generate composition at runtime we only need one CompositionDefinition in this block

_field_tag_reference_64.name: Forge Outro Composition Template#We'll write camera and player positions into this template for Forge outros
Forge Static View Composition Template#We'll write camera positions into this template for previewing static views

_field_block_64.name: Game Type Cinematic Names#Cinematic objects can specify that they only should be used in certain game types by name (i.e. only the CTF intro cinematic)
Cinematic Player Animations#We lookup here to decide which animation to use for a given player in Forge intros/outros

_field_char_integer.name: Player Index In Team#This animation will only be used for the player with this index in their team

_field_char_enum.name: Team Size#This animation will only be used if animating player's team size matches this rule
Team Relation#This animation will only be used if the animating player's team's relation to the cinematic viewer's team matches this rule

_field_string_id.name: Animation Name#We lookup this animation name in the animation graph referenced above

_field_tag_reference_64.name: Default Boundary Shader#If we're rendering a boundary and it doesn't have an object-specific boundary override, use this
